newsitem.title: TANZANIA: Tanzanian airline chief rejects merger talk.
newsitem.headline: Tanzanian airline chief rejects merger talk.

text.p: State-owned Air Tanzania Ltd's (ATC) chairman has rejected talk of merging with Uganda Airlines and Alliance Air because there are currently no legal provisions to allow it.

"We cannot merge because there is a law -- an act which established Air Tanzania and it does not allow a merger. The law is still operational unless the parliament amends the law," ATC chairman Abbas Sykes told Reuters in an interview on Tuesday.
He said a merger deal with ATC should involve a reputable international carrier such as Deutsche Lufthansa AG or British Airways Plc.

"That would be ideal -- they've got the muscle. You cannot survive if you are both weak," he said. He cited the partnership between Kenya Airways and Royal Dutch Airlines KLM as a good example of the sort preferred by the ATC board.

Sykes spoke in reaction to a proposal last month endorsed by Tanzanian Transport Minister William Kusila for a merger of the national carriers of Uganda and Tanzania with Alliance Air, which Uganda and Tanzania own with South African Airways.
The proposal has been greeted with strong opposition by ATC's board who claim the deal could embroil ATC in a massively loss-making venture.

Sykes denied claims that the ATC board would resign if the merger went ahead, saying the board was unified in its opposition and would "fight it out". He said the merger proposal was frought with risk because the airline's losses over two years of operation exceeded $20 million.

"In less than two years they've made losses more than $20 million -- their aircraft are leased -- there's no profit," Sykes said. The ATC chairman said of the three airlines, only ATC owned its own aircraft, two short/medium haul Boeing 737-200 jet aircraft and a 60's vintage Fokker, F-27 turbo-prop.
"Take Kenya -- they will benefit quite a lot from KLM. There's transfer of technology, employment and training. But Alliance?," Sykes added.

He said the wrangle over the merger had delayed moves for ATC's privatisation which he saw as now taking place "sometime next year." He said the transport ministry's enthusiasm in pushing for a merger was curious given the government's stated aim to let the private sector run the economy.

The concept of a regional airline merger dates back about three years, Sykes said. The original proposal sought a merger of national carriers of Southern Africa Development Community nations in order to compete with major international airlines.
There was no immediate reaction from Uganda Airlines, Alliance Air or the governments of Tanzania and Uganda.
